oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Four women quilting in Hoyt Wakefield's home

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Houses; Interiors; Women; Quilting
Quilts; Quilting
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Four unidentified women working on a quilt in Hoyt Wakefield's home. The women are at one corner of the frame with a cabinet standing in the corner of the room behind them. A closed plank door can be seen in the background, and an open door leading to a room with a bed is visible on the right.

The quilting bee became a tradition probably during the 19th Century. Many bees were simply an occasion wherein women assisted one another in finishing quilts. They eventually became an opportunity for women to gather in a social environment. The bee itself often featured a large wooden frame around which many women would work on the same quilt.
